title: 112_s2171
content: The "Export Promotion Act of 2012" is also known as the "Improved Coordination of Export Promotion Activities of Federal Agencies by the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee." The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to include duties for the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee (TPCC), such as reviewing agency budgets for export promotion activities before submission to the Office of Management and Budget. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to include duties for the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee (TPCC), such as identifying countries for trade agreements to increase US exports. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to include new duties for the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee (TPCC), such as maximizing partnerships with agencies and improving educational outreach to small- and medium-sized businesses. The Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee (TPCC) is required to clearly define the roles and responsibilities of each agency involved in export promotion and financing. Additionally, the TPCC chairperson must submit an annual report to congressional committees detailing the strategic plan and its implementation. The TPCC evaluates agency performance in export promotion and financing, reviews annual budgets, and reports on the implementation of specific sections of the FREEDOM Support Act. The Export Promotion Act of 2012 requires the Comptroller General of the United States to submit a report every 2 years assessing the effectiveness of the TPCC, including operational efficiency and effectiveness. The Export Promotion Act of 2012 mandates a biennial report by the Comptroller General of the United States to evaluate the TPCC's effectiveness in coordinating Federal export promotion and financing activities, reducing duplication among agencies, and improving efficiency. The Comptroller General evaluates the TPCC's effectiveness in coordinating Federal export promotion and financing activities, reducing duplication among agencies, and improving efficiency. The report considers the changing strategy of the TPCC and includes relevant information on its overall effectiveness. Appropriate congressional committees are defined as specific committees in Congress. The TPCC coordinates with relevant agencies to publish export promotion and financing information on Export.gov. This includes details outlined in subsection (c)(10) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988. The President will issue an executive order and regulations to empower the TPCC chairperson to fulfill duties and develop a strategic plan within 18 months of the Export Promotion Act of 2012. SEC. 3. Effective deployment of resources by the United States and Foreign Commercial Service. Section 2301(c)(4) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to require the Secretary to conduct a global assessment of overseas markets to identify potential for increasing US exports and redeploy resources accordingly. Recommendations from US exporters must be considered within 180 days of the enactment of the Export Promotion Act of 2012. The Export Promotion Act of 2012 requires the Secretary to submit a report on the global assessment and a redeployment plan for Commercial Service personnel and resources every 5 years. The Secretary must consider recommendations from US exporters within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. "Strengthened commercial diplomacy to boost US exports." The Foreign Service Act of 1980 is amended to require each chief of mission to develop a plan for effective diplomacy to enhance US exports, in consultation with various government officials and agencies. The Foreign Service Act of 1980 is amended to require each chief of mission to develop a plan for effective diplomacy to enhance US exports, in consultation with various government officials and agencies. The plan must be submitted to the Secretary for review before implementation. Additionally, assessments of efforts to promote the exportation of US goods and services will be conducted for members of the Service with responsibilities relating to economic affairs. The Foreign Service Act of 1980 is amended to include an assessment of the effectiveness of diplomacy in promoting exports of US goods and services. This amendment adds a new paragraph to Section 209(b) of the Act.
